cards.definition: A record of sale used to trigger compensation calculations within incent; sometimes referred to as transaction, subscription or deal.
bestPractices: Establish clear transaction validation rules before data enters the SPM system
Implement real-time transaction feeds from source systems (CRM, ERP)
Define transaction lifecycle stages with clear ownership at each stage
Create exception queues for transactions that fail validation
watchOutFor: Duplicate transactions from multiple source systems
Timing mismatches between booking and recognition dates
Currency conversion issues for international deals
cards.whyItMatters: A record of sale used to trigger compensation calculations within incent; sometimes referred to as transaction, subscription or deal. Transaction data forms the foundation of all compensation calculations. Accurate transaction capture ensures reps are paid correctly and finance can reconcile commissions to revenue.
cards.example: A $50,000 software license order is booked in Salesforce on March 15. The SPM system ingests this transaction nightly and assigns 100% credit to the account executive, retiring $50,000 against their Q1 quota.

cards.definition: A document issued to the buyer by the seller, listing the goods or services provided and the amount owed.

cards.whyItMatters: A document issued to the buyer by the seller, listing the goods or services provided and the amount owed. Transaction data forms the foundation of all compensation calculations. Accurate transaction capture ensures reps are paid correctly and finance can reconcile commissions to revenue.
cards.example: After a customer signs a 3-year contract, the billing team generates an invoice for Year 1. This invoice triggers commission payment on the first-year value while Years 2-3 are deferred.

cards.example: An enterprise deal closes on December 28 with a $1M booking. Per policy, Q4 commission is calculated on bookings through December 31, so this deal counts toward Q4 attainment and triggers accelerators.

cards.definition: The set of guidelines or principles that determine how and when revenue is recognized in the financial statements.
bestPractices: Align compensation triggers with ASC 606 revenue recognition principles
Document clear rules for multi-element and subscription deals
Implement automated recognition schedules in your SPM platform
Create audit trails for all recognition adjustments
watchOutFor: Compensation paid before revenue is recognizable
Complex multi-year deals with unclear milestone definitions
Inconsistent treatment of renewals vs. new business
cards.whyItMatters: The set of guidelines or principles that determine how and when revenue is recognized in the financial statements. Revenue recognition timing directly impacts when and how much sales reps are compensated. Misalignment between recognition rules and compensation triggers creates disputes and financial risk.

cards.definition: The highest level of the organization that encompasses the overall strategic direction, policies, and management of the entire company.

cards.definition: The specific type or segment of customers that the position is responsible for managing, such as key accounts, small and medium enterprises (SMEs), or geographic-specific clients. This ensures targeted and effective customer relationship management.

Create role families that share common compensation structures

Unclear boundaries between adjacent roles
Roles defined by activity rather than outcomes

cards.whyItMatters: A commission structure where a fixed percentage of sales revenue is paid as commission for each sale, regardless of the sales amount. Incentive structures translate performance into earnings. Well-designed incentives motivate target achievement while managing cost within budget constraints.
cards.example: A rep achieves 120% quota attainment. Their plan pays 8% commission up to quota and 12% above quota. On $1.2M against a $1M quota, they earn $80,000 (8% of $1M) plus $24,000 (12% of $200K) = $104,000.
